Cognition
4. Cognition

Epistemology is another subject in which Gregory’s thought has
received much attention (e.g. Elie 1937; Dal Pra 1956; Gál
1977; Eckermann 1978; V. Wendland’s chapter in Oberman 1981,
242–300; Tachau 1988, 358–71; Bermon 2007; Mandrella 2016;
Girard 2017). Gregory maintains a non-realist position that universals
are formed by the soul and only after the mind has previous
apprehensions of singular things. Thus sensory experience plays a
major role in intellectual cognition. For simple cognition Gregory
adopts the common terminology of the dichotomy between intuitive and
abstractive cognition, although the difference between the two is
based on the objects rather than the modes of cognition. For Gregory,
intuitive cognition terminates immediately at the extramental object,
but abstractive terminates at the object’s species in the soul.
The fact that Gregory made room for such species in his theory of
cognition has not gone unnoticed (Corvino 1978; Spruit 2013, 309–313;
Mandrella 2016, 220–223). It has been described as the only difference
between Ockham and Rimini in the epistemology of simple cognition
(Mandrella 2016, 223). Still, Gregory’s use of species
conditions his take on universal concepts to such an extent that he
embraces a view Ockham explicitly rejected as especially irrational,
namely the view that universal concepts are qualities really distinct
from mental acts and that remain in the soul independently of whether
a mental act is directed at them or not (Girard 2017, 263).

Inspired by some of Ockham’s successors, Gregory argues against
the Venerable Inceptor’s claim that via intuitive cognition one
could determine whether a thing does exist or not (Tachau 1988, 363).
In agreement with Auriol against most contemporaries, however, Gregory
also holds that one can have an intuitive cognition of an object that
does not exist, as for example when we see a “broken”
pencil in a glass of water, when there is only an unbroken pencil in
reality. But Auriol is wrong in claiming that this is an instance of
an intuitive cognition of something absent (Tachau 1988, 361), because
for Gregory the cognition is really caused by the species of some
present object, although perhaps not the object that the mind thinks
it is. Therefore Gregory does not adopt Auriol’s definition of
intuitive cognition as the cognition when the soul merely thinks that
the object is present. In any case the dichotomy is different for
Gregory because he maintains that abstractive cognition is also
somewhat intuitive, since the species of the object is known
immediately and therefore intuitively.

When it comes to the object of complex cognition, or scientific
knowledge, Gregory’s inspiration was Adam Wodeham, who built on
some of Walter Chatton’s ideas in developing the complexe
significabile. Ockham held that the object of scientific
knowledge is the conclusion of a syllogism, and Gregory rejects this.
Chatton’s alternative was that scientific knowledge has as its
object things outside the mind. Gregory also denies this, because

if this were the case, many sciences would be about contingent things
that could be different than they are, whereas for strict science the
object must be eternal and necessary. Every being, however, besides
God is contingent and not necessary. If things outside the mind were
the objects of the sciences, then many sciences, physical and
geometrical, and many others, would be about things other than God,
and therefore about contingent things (Rimini 1979, 6; Brown 1998a,
171).


One can see here how Gregory’s stress on the overarching
contingency of creation connects with his epistemology.

Gregory chooses as the object of scientific knowledge the alternative
offered by Adam Wodeham. Chatton’s notion of “thing”
in scientific knowledge was the state of affairs signified by both the
negative and the affirmative proposition. For example, “Socrates
is sitting” and “Socrates is not sitting” signify
for Chatton the same thing, not Socrates, not sitting, and not the
propositions, but somehow the whole Socrates’s-being-seated.
Although Chatton had his reasons for his theory, Wodeham modified it
in a useful way, differentiating between positive and negative states
of affairs. Thus for Wodeham, each proposition has its own total
significate that is only complexly signifiable (complexe
significabile), so that Socrates’s-being-seated and
Socrates’s-not-being-seated are two different things, the
objects of scientific knowledge.

Gregory adopted Wodeham’s theory and tailored it where necessary
to his own thought. The complexe significabile, once thought
to be Gregory’s invention, is neither the proposition itself,
nor individual things in the world, nor the arrangement of things in
the world. The exact status of Gregory’s complexe
significabile has been much discussed. In a nutshell, there are
three main interpretations. The first one builds on Gregory’s
claim that the complexe significabile is nothing
(nihil), and thus holds that Gregory does not defend logical
realism (Biard 1989, 183, Libera 2002, 217; Bermon 2007,
166–167). The second interpretation builds on Gregory’s
claim that there are senses of “something”
(aliquid), “thing” (res) and
“being” (ens) that can apply to the complexe
significabile, and insists that the
complexe significabile must be something mind-independent
because of this, although it is not an entity (Elie 1936, 28, 174;
Nuchelmans 1973, 73). The third interpretation concludes from the fact
that the complexe significabile is said to be something but
not an entity to the fact that the complexe significabile
must be mind-dependent or in the mind (Trapp 1977, 58; Mandrella 2016,
208, as a legitimate hypothesis). Another point of debate concerns how
one should evaluate Gregory’s take on Wodeham’s ideas.
That debate opposes those who consider Gregory’s developments as
a clearer elaboration of the concept (Bermon 2007, 169, 173), and
those who believe Gregory blurred the clear picture Wodeham had given,
thus making the doctrine of the complexe significabile an
easy target (Gàl 1977, 70; Nuchelmans 1980, 185–186; Zupko
1994–1997, 218).

Gregory famously listed three ways in which some complexe
significabile could be said to be true: first, because a
proposition signifying it would be true; second, with reference to the
uncreated truth; third, because it is the case (i.e. it obtains).
These descriptions have sometimes been read as competing ones (Elie
1936, 175). If there is a general agreement that the first way must be
left aside as too weak, since it makes the truth of the complexe
significabilia depend on enunciations, it has been claimed that
the second and third ways are compatible with each other (Libera 2002,
253; Conti 2004, 482–483) and even complementary (Bermon 2007,
161–162).

It is also known that Gregory differed from Wodeham in the way he
thought about “assenting to” and “dissenting
from” such complexe significabilia, an issue which had
occupied Chatton at length. Wodeham thought of assent pretty much as
an act of the will (Bermon 2007, 319), that can contingently be added
over and above a formed proposition. Gregory distinguishes two kinds
of mental propositions: mental propositions that are not expressed in
a given language, and mental propositions that are expressed in a
given language and that derive from the first kind. For Gregory,
Wodeham’s claim is true only of linguistic mental propositions
(Bermon 2007, 343–344). For non-linguistic mental propositions,
it is impossible to dissociate the formation and the acts of assent or
dissent. Formation and assent are associated in such a way that
Gregory can claim that assent is a mental utterance (Bermon 2007,
331).

Gregory applied the notion to a host of philosophical problems, such
as future contingents, and through him the complexe
significabile became the common intellectual property of
continental thinkers, and parallel notions are found in many important
later intellectuals. More particularly, recent studies have focused on
the reception of Gregory’s doctrine in Pierre Ceffons (Nannini
2015; Corbini 2020).

Apart from complexe significabilia, another point of contact
between Wodeham and Gregory in connection with complex cognition is
the debate on the capacity that non-human animals have to make a
judgement (i.e. Reina 1986; Perler 2006, 89–94; Oelze 2018,
123–129).  Gregory claims that we need to ascribe sensory
judgments to non-human animals in order to account for their
behaviour, especially for the different responses a same individual
can exhibit to a same stimulus (Oelze 2018, 126–127).

With regard to the mental proposition, although Gregory defends that
the intellect can indeed have simultaneous acts (Friedman 2009, 114;
Dubouclez 2014, 342–347), nevertheless he holds, as Durand of
Saint-Pourçain did, that the mental proposition must consist of
a single act (Friedman 2009, 115).
